    Targeting Aldose Reductase for the Treatment of Diabetes Complications and Inflammatory Diseases: New Insights and Future Directions

    • Rosanna Maccari*
      •  and 
    • Rosaria Ottanà
    View Author Information
    Dipartimento di Scienze del Farmaco e dei Prodotti per la Salute, Università degli Studi di Messina, Polo Universitario dell’Annunziata, 98168 Messina, Italy
    *E-mail: [email protected]. Telephone +39906766406.
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2015, 58, 5, 2047–2067
    Publication Date (Web):November 6, 2014

    Publication History

    • Received13 June 2014
    • Published online17 November 2014
    • Published inissue 12 March 2015
    https://doi.org/10.1021/jm500907a
    Copyright © 2014 American Chemical Society

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Aldose reductase (AR) is an aldo–keto reductase that has been widely investigated as an enzyme crucially involved in the pathogenesis of chronic complications associated with diabetes mellitus. Recently it was established that AR also acts as a key mediator of certain oxidative and inflammatory signaling pathways that are involved in the development of different human pathologies, such as cardiovascular disorders, sepsis, and cancer. These findings have renewed interest in the search for new AR inhibitors (ARIs) with improved profiles as potential therapeutic agents. In this review, recent advances in the field and promising future directions for developing ARIs are discussed.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Aldose reductase (AR; AKR1B1, human enzyme) is a cytoplasmatic aldo–keto reductase (AKR) that is present in most human cells. During the past 4 decades, it has been widely investigated as an enzyme critically involved in the onset and progression of various pathologies associated with diabetes mellitus (DM).(1-8)
    Under normal conditions, the major physiological function of AR appears to be the degradation of toxic aldehydes originated from lipid peroxidation, such as 4-hydroxy-trans-2-nonenal (HNE) and its glutathione adduct GS-HNE. However, in DM, this enzyme plays a pivotal role in mediating hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress and consequent tissue and vascular damage, through the NADPH-dependent reduction of glucose to sorbitol and consequent modifications of both cellular osmolarity and redox status. Accordingly, AR inhibitors (ARIs) have been shown to prevent or slow the progression of DM-associated pathologies, such as neuropathy, retinopathy, cataracts, and nephropathy, both in animal models and humans.(9-18) Therefore, AR has received a great deal of attention as an attractive therapeutic target for designing drugs able to counteract the development of long-term diabetic complications.
    On this basis, up to now, a large variety of small molecule ARIs have been discovered and many of them have been evaluated in preclinical and clinical trials.(4-6, 19-21) However, their development was often hampered by pharmacokinetic drawbacks, low in vivo efficacy, or adverse side effects. Currently, only epalrestat (Figure 1) is commercially available as ARI approved for the management of diabetic neuropathy.(22) Several clinical trials confirmed that this drug can slow the progression of diabetic neuropathy and can provide a significant improvement in the associated symptoms, without any severe side effects after long-term administration.(14, 23, 24) Nevertheless, epalrestat is currently used only in few Asian countries (such as Japan and India) and it was suggested that its efficacy should be elucidated by further long-term comparative studies in different patient populations.(24)
    Among ARIs that entered clinical trials, a few molecules showed clinically suitable profiles. In fact, sorbinil (Figure 1), which was the first extensively tested ARI with good acivity both in vitro and in vivo, was withdrawn from clinical trials because of hypersensitivity reactions that were related to its hydantoin ring.(25, 26) Imirestat (Figure 1), a fluorene analog of sorbinil, also showed appreciable in vivo activity but was discontinued because of its toxicity.(20) Tolrestat (Figure 1), a carboxylic acid derivative that was launched on the market in 1989, was withdrawn worldwide in 1996 because of its severe liver toxicity versus poor in vivo efficacy.(6, 27) Zopolrestat(28) and zenarestat (Figure 1) were also withdrawn from clinical trials because of liver and/or renal toxicity. On the other hand, fidarestat (Figure 1) exhibited higher efficacy and selectivity than its parent sorbinil and it was shown to provide beneficial clinical effects in the treatment of diabetic neuropathy, with no significant adverse effects. Therefore, currently fidarestat is one of the most promising drug candidates among ARIs.(10, 18, 29) Analogous spirosuccinimides minalrestat and ranirestat as well as carboxylic acid ponalrestat (Figure 1) also showed appreciable activity and safety profiles in clinical trials.(30-32) However, ponalrestat showed limited efficacy in improving diabetic neuropathy, whereas clinical trials conducted for ranirestat provided encouraging results in the treatment of this serious DM complication.(18, 31)
    Therefore, despite the difficulties in developing effective ARIs, the inhibition of AR has continued to be considered an attractive route to prevent or manage diabetic complications.
    Moreover, in recent years, important advances in understanding the physiological and pathological roles of AR have prompted a renewed interest in designing and evaluating ARIs. In particular, it was demonstrated that this enzyme is overexpressed under various oxidative conditions and is involved in inflammatory signaling under both hyperglycemic and normoglycemic conditions. Accordingly, known ARIs, such as sorbinil, tolrestat, zopolrestat, fidarestat, were shown to prevent cellular inflammatory events.(33-37) These findings suggested that AR inhibition could be a useful strategy not only in the management of DM and its chronic complications but also in the treatment of other serious human diseases that are associated with increased tissue inflammation, such as rheumatoid arthritis, sepsis, atherosclerosis, and cancer.
    Thus, today AR can be considered an emerging target for therapeutic interventions in different pathologies, and consequently the development of effective ARIs with improved therapeutic potential is demanded.
    Several reviews described these recent advances from a biochemical/biological standpoint.(7, 38-41) In this review, we will focus on the main challenges that medicinal chemists must tackle to identify new, safer, and more efficacious ARIs as drug candidates and will highlight advances in the design and optimization of these agents in the past decade. In this context, the selectivity toward AR over other highly homologous AKRs as well as the differential inhibition of AR depending on the nature of the substrate may be considered as major requirements. Main aspects of the current knowledge about the involvement of AR in pathogenic events that underlie the onset of human diseases are also reported.

    Implications of Aldose Reductase in the Development of Diabetes Complications

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    DM is a chronic disease characterized by impaired response of target tissues to insulin (insulin resistance) and/or progressively reduced function of pancreatic β-cells, with consequent hyperglycemia and metabolic dysfunctions. This serious pathology currently affects almost 400 million people worldwide, and especially as a consequence of the soaring rates of type 2 DM and obesity in both developed and developing countries, its prevalence is predicted to rise to about 10% of total world population by 2030.(42)
    In DM, both prolonged hyperglycemia and insulin resistance can induce blood vessel and nerve damage as well as cell signaling alterations, finally resulting in the onset of long-term complications, such as retinopathy, cataracts, neuropathy, nephropathy, accelerated atherosclerosis, and increased risk of cardiovascular diseases, which are the main causes of morbidity and mortality in diabetic patients. Normalizing glycemia by means of prompt intensive antihyperglycemic treatments can delay the development of long-term diabetic complications that are caused by microvascular damage, without reducing the increased cardiovascular risk derived from macrovascular injury.(43, 44) Consequently, the emergence of these debilitating pathologies appears to be unavoidable in the majority of diabetic patients.(2) This makes the identification of new drugs for the treatment of diabetic complications a still urgent therapeutic need.
    Hyperglycemia-induced tissue injury was shown to be mediated by several intracellular mechanisms. Out of them, the increased flux of glucose through the polyol pathway plays a pivotal role. AR is the first and rate-limiting enzyme of this metabolic pathway in which it catalyzes the NADPH-dependent reduction of glucose to sorbitol. This latter is subsequently oxidized to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase (SD), with concomitant reduction of NAD+ (Figure 2).
    Under euglycemic conditions, the reduction of glucose is a minor function of AR which regards less than 3% of the metabolized amount of this aldose because AR has a relatively low affinity toward this substrate. Instead, glucose mainly enters the glycolytic pathway, following its conversion to glucose 6-phosphate by hexokinase. Indeed, AR can catalyze the NADPH-dependent reduction of a wide variety of aromatic and aliphatic carbonyl substrates, and its catalytic effectiveness is markedly higher toward several hydrophobic saturated and unsaturated aldehydes than toward aldoses, particularly glucose.(3, 8) On this basis, the main physiological role of AR appears to be the reduction of several toxic medium or long-chain aldehydes originated during lipid peroxidation, such as HNE and their glutathione adducts.(8, 45, 46) Modulation of cell osmolarity, through the production of osmotically active compounds, such as sorbitol in the kidneys, was proposed as another function of AR.(3, 7) In addition, the recently emerged involvement of AR in cell growth and signaling reveals other physiological roles of the enzyme.(7, 8, 33, 35)
    In contrast, under hyperglycemic conditions, AR converts the excess of intracellular glucose (which can vary up to one-third of total glucose amount depending on organ and tissue) to sorbitol, after hexokinase saturation, in tissues possessing insulin-independent glucose uptake, such as lens, retina, peripheral nerves, kidney, and erythrocytes.(1)
    The significantly increased flux of glucose through the polyol pathway originates a complex cascade of multiple downstream events that can culminate in tissue and vascular damage, reduced nerve blood flow, and decreased nerve conduction velocity, thus critically contributing to the etiology of chronic complications associated with DM (Figure 2).(1-3, 8, 15, 21)
    In particular, in the lens, intracellular accumulation of the osmotically active sorbitol gives rise to osmotic stress, swelling, and membrane permeability changes, thus promoting cataractogenesis (Figure 2). However, in other sites, such as in blood vessels, nerves, and retina, intracellular sorbitol concentration generally appears to be too low to cause a serious osmotic imbalance.(1, 16)
    Indeed, in most tissues, hyperglycemia-induced damage is prevalently mediated by substantially increased cellular susceptibility to oxidative stress. In fact, NADPH depletion, due to the activation of the polyol pathway in hyperglycemic conditions, impairs the activity of other NADPH-dependent enzymes, particularly glutathione reductase, and gives rise to an imbalance between the generation of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) and cellular antioxidant defense (Figure 2).(8, 47) Concomitantly, the altered NADH/NAD+ ratio, described as “pseudohypoxia”, which results from the NAD+ consumption during the oxidation of sorbitol to fructose by SD, brings about further metabolic and signaling changes by exacerbating redox imbalance (Figure 2).(48)
    The increased catabolism of glucose through the polyol pathway also produces glycative stress by promoting the intracellular formation of advanced glycation end products (AGEs) (Figure 2).(49) The end product of the polyol pathway, fructose, is more reactive as glycating agent than glucose and is capable of reacting with amino groups of proteins to form Schiff bases that, in turn, undergo rearrangement and oxidative reactions to give AGEs.(21, 50) These latter can cause alterations of the functions of proteins as well as impair cellular signaling and, at the same time, contribute to the intracellular production of ROS.(5, 6) Fructose may also be converted to reactive carbonyl compounds, such as dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP), glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, and methylglyoxal, which further contribute to the formation of AGEs.(40)
    In addition, DHAP can be reduced to glycerol 3-phosphate which is a precursor of diacylglycerol (DAG). DAG, in turn, activates protein kinase C (PKC) which also promotes the intracellular ROS production (Figure 2).(35, 51)
    Under hyperglycemic conditions, ROS-induced lipid peroxidation with formation of cytotoxic aldehydes, such as HNE, is one of the most important consequences of increased oxidative stress. HNE can cause AR up-regulation, thus originating a positive feedback that amplifies hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress.(8, 52-54) Moreover, HNE can propagate oxidative signaling by acting as a cytotoxic second messenger. In fact, it is a particularly reactive aldehyde, which at high concentrations is able to react with various cellular nucleophiles, such as amino acid residues of proteins, producing cellular damage. HNE-modified proteins were found to be present in several pathological conditions, such as atherosclerosis and neurodegenerative and autoimmune diseases, and they were also used as oxidative stress markers.(45)
    HNE and its glutathione adduct GS-HNE are converted by AR to 1,4-dihydroxynonene (DHN) and GS-DHN, respectively (Figure 2). However, in the presence of intracellular glutathione, GS-HNE is the predominant metabolite derived from HNE which prevails over DHN, likely due to the high reactivity of the aldehyde with glutathione. GS-HNE, in turn, is the only parent molecule that can be converted to GS-DHN, since free DHN is unable to react with nucleophiles such as glutathione. Therefore, AR-catalyzed reduction of GS-HNE is the major pathway that generates GS-DHN and, accordingly, inhibition of AR was shown to reduce cellular levels of GS-DHN.(45, 54)
    On the basis of recent studies, GS-DHN was recognized as a potent mediator of oxidative stress-induced cellular signaling pathways via activation of phospholipase C (PLC)/DAG/PKC/nuclear transcription factor κB (NF-κB) pathway (Figure 2).(8, 39) It was demonstrated that the hyperglycemia-induced activation of the polyol pathway can control the activation of PLC/DAG/PKC/NF-κB cascade and, in fact, upstream AR inhibition can extinguish these signaling events.(8, 33, 34, 38, 47, 51)
    The activation of NF-κB is a key step in the inflammatory response, since it regulates the transcription of numerous genes involved in inflammation, apoptosis, cell growth, and adhesion, thus determining the expression of proinflammatory cytokines, growth factors, adhesion molecules, tumor necrosis factor α (TNF-α), and inducible NO synthase (iNOS) (Figure 2).(47, 55)
    Inflammation and oxidative stress can promote endothelial cell apoptosis, vascular hyperplasia, infiltration, and adhesion of inflammatory cells to vascular walls, which are events involved in the formation of atherosclerotic lesions as well as in diabetic nephropathy and myocardial ischemia reperfusion injury.(15, 34, 38, 40, 43, 52, 56, 57)
    Furthermore, cellular production of interleukin 6 (IL-6), IL-1β, and TNF-α consequent to NF-κB activation can mediate inflammatory mechanisms leading to pancreatic β-cell apoptosis and decreased insulin secretion. Inflammatory cytokines also induce iNOS expression which results in impaired insulin signaling in target tissues.(58)
    Accordingly, in mice, inflammation and insulin resistance were shown to be associated with the upstream production of HNE and its metabolites GS-HNE and GS-DHN induced in adipocytes by high glucose and oxidative stress.(59)
    Recently, a novel AR-mediated mechanism that supports inflammatory signaling pathways was demonstrated in diabetic mice. In fact, the increased flux of glucose through the polyol pathway also decreases NAD+/NADH ratio, thus impairing the activity of sirtuins and other NAD+-dependent deacetylases. This, in turn, prevents the sirtuin-1-dependent deacetylation of Egr-1 (“immediate early response gene”) and maintains this latter in its acetylated form that triggers prothrombotic and proinflammatory events and subsequent endothelial dysfunction, vascular injury, and atherosclerosis.(60)
    On the basis of all these findings, hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress and inflammation can be recognized as unifying pathogenetic mechanisms involved in the development of both insulin resistance/deficiency and long-term complications of DM.(8, 47, 58, 61) Therefore, AR implication in oxidative and inflammatory signaling further validates this enzyme as a crucial target in the development of new agents for the therapy of DM-associated pathologies and stimulates the search for new and safer ARIs. In view of this, as suggested by several authors, new and old ARIs could be evaluated with redesigned screening procedures that allow the assessment of their effectiveness in interrupting inflammatory signaling and preventing consequent vascular damage in diabetic patients.
    Finally, much evidence supports the hypothesis that AR gene polymorphisms may modulate the susceptibility to diabetic microvascular complications, although contrasting findings have also been reported. In certain populations of diabetic patients, the Z-2 allele of the AR gene promoter region was found to be associated with increased risk of diabetic nephropathy and retinopathy as well as with increased AR expression, whereas the Z + 2 allele appeared to determine reduced susceptibility to diabetic complications. The C-106T polymorphism of the AR gene was also found to be involved in the development of nephropathy and neuropathy in certain diabetic patients.(62-67)

    Aldose Reductase as an Emerging Therapeutic Target for Inflammatory Pathologies

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Recent studies in both cell cultures and animal models demonstrated a critical implication of AR in inflammatory signaling pathways, not only in DM but also under normoglycemic conditions.(53, 68, 69)
    Besides hyperglycemia, several other factors, such as lipopolysaccharides, proinflammatory cytokines, growth factors, and allergens, can stimulate intracellular ROS production.(39, 53, 70) In many inflammatory cell types, such as phagocytes, monocytes, and macrophages, these factors can activate NADPH oxidase, which catalyzes the formation of superoxide anions from the reduction of oxygen, using NADPH as electron donor. Superoxide anions further generate ROS, thus substaining cellular oxidative stress.(53)
    As mentioned above, ROS, in turn, can induce both lipid peroxidation and AR expression. Therefore, in the presence of oxidative stress, even under normoglycemic conditions, AR-catalyzed reduction of glutathione adducts of lipid-derived aldehydes, such as GS-HNE, is a key upstream event which is able to propagate the oxidative/inflammatory signaling through the activation of the PLC/PKC/NF-κB cascade (Figure 3). The subsequent transcription of numerous proinflammatory genes regulated by NF-κB amplifies and sustains inflammation and cytotoxicity. In fact, the treatment of lipopolysaccharide-stimulated macrophages with different known ARIs (sorbinil, tolrestat, zopolrestat) prevented both the activation of NF-κB and the production of proinflammatory cytokines and inflammatory molecules, such as NO, prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), and cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2).(35, 53)
    On the whole, AR gives a substantial contribution to the pathogenic course of several inflammatory pathologies, such as rheumatoid arthritis, sepsis, asthma, cardiovascular diseases, and cancer, besides DM and its complications.
    In animal models of systemic inflammation induced by bacterial endotoxins, the treatment with sorbinil, fidarestat, tolrestat, or zopolrestat prevented ROS generation and attenuated both NF-κB activation and release of proinflammatory cytokines, chemokines, PGE2, and NO, thus indicating that ARIs could be considered as potential drugs to treat endotoxin-related inflammatory diseases, such as sepsis, asthma, and uveitis.(33, 34, 36, 37, 41, 53)
    Recently, several new ARIs (compounds 1–4, Figure 4) were also shown to possess promising properties as potential agents for treating inflammatory diseases (Figure 4).(71-74)
    In addition, growing evidence supports the involvement of AR-mediated oxidative and inflammatory signaling pathways in the pathophysiology of cardiovascular diseases, such as atherosclerosis, vasculopathy, hypertension, endothelial dysfunction, and myocardial ischemia, in normoglycemic individuals. In endothelial cells, the inhibition of AR was shown both to reduce NF-κB activation and to attenuate TNF-α-induced up-regulation of adhesion molecules.(34) Moreover, ARIs significantly reduced cardiac ischemic injury in human AR-expressing transgenic mice by attenuating oxidative stress and apoptosis.(75, 76) All these data support the hypothesis that targeting AR may be a new effective approach to the treatment or prevention of vascular and myocardial dysfunctions in both diabetic and nondiabetic patients and have prompted preclinical and clinical evaluation of ARIs in this area.(38, 40)
    Furthermore, recent studies demonstrated that AR is overexpressed and up-regulated in a broad variety of solid tumors and leukemias.(68, 77) AR was found to be an essential component of carcinogenic inflammatory signaling pathways and, in addition, to be implicated in the development of drug resistance in different cancer cells.(21, 68, 78) The central AR-catalyzed event in oxidative stress-mediated carcinogenesis once again appears to be the reduction of GS-HNE to GS-DHN which promotes the propagation of cytotoxic signaling. The subsequent activation of NF-κB was shown to be involved in cancer cell survival, proliferation, adhesion, invasion, and angiogenesis.(68)
    Increased oxidative stress and NF-κB activation are also predominant aspects in cancer cachexia.(79) AR inhibition by ponalrestat was found to provide benefit by reducing cancer-induced cachexia symptoms through the control of certain inflammatory pathways.(80)
    In human colon tumor cells, AR inhibition by means of sorbinil or tolrestat prevented the activation of NF-κB and PKC as well as the overexpression of COX-2 and the consequent PGE2 production induced by TNF-α, HNE, and GS-HNE but did not counteract the cytotoxic effects of already formed GS-DHN.(81, 82)
    ARIs also induced tumor cell apoptosis by up-regulating death receptors and proapoptotic proteins and down-regulating cell survival proteins.(83) Moreover, they were shown to prevent growth and invasiveness of tumors by suppressing the production of growth factors, matrix metalloproteinases, and adhesion molecules which promote angiogenesis.(84)
    All these findings strongly suggest that AR could be a promising novel target for chemotherapeutic and chemopreventive agents capable to treat cancer as well as to improve the effectiveness of certain antitumor drugs. However, since the available data on ARI efficacy regard mainly colon cancer, additional investigations on different tumor types would be desirable to further validate ARIs as potential chemotherapeutic agents.(68)

    Structure of Aldose Reductase

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The first AR structures to be solved by means of X-ray crystallography, in 1992, were those of the recombinant human placenta and pig lens enzymes.(85, 86) Afterward, X-ray crystallographic studies solved several other structures of AR cocrystallized with various substrates and inhibitors, thus giving important insights into the binding sites and interaction modes of substrates and inhibitors.(4, 5, 19, 87-89)
    The human enzyme consists of a single peptide chain of 316 amino acid residues that folds as an eight-stranded β/α-barrel with a small β-sheet capping at the N-terminal of the barrel and a C-terminal extension comprising residues 275–315 (Figure 5). The substrate-binding site is located in a large and deep cleft at the C-terminal of the barrel, with the pyridine cofactor NADP+ bound at the bottom, and it is delimited by loops connecting the central β-strands with the external α-helices.(85)
    The cofactor is held within the cleft by a flexible loop (residues Gly213-Ser226) named “safety-belt” loop.(90) Conformational motions of the safety-belt are responsible for the binding or release of the cofactor. A “closed” conformation of the safety-belt, with the cofactor partially covered by the loop and thus locked into the pocket, is present in most holoenzyme structures. A partially opened conformation of this loop was also observed only in a small number of AR holoenzyme molecules.(90) Instead, in the absence of NADP+, the safety-belt loop of the apoenzyme assumes a significantly different “open” conformation.(91) Gly213, Ser214, and Ser226 act as hinges allowing the loop to interconvert its conformation. Another amino acid residue of the loop, Trp219, plays a key role by establishing interactions with Cys298 and Arg293 that stabilize the “closed” and “open“ conformations, respectively.(91) In addition, in the closed conformation of the safety-belt loop, Trp219 can engage effective interactions with ligands.(90)
    The conformational changes that accompany the binding and release of NADP(H) are strictly associated with the catalytic mechanism of AR. The binding of the substrate to the enzyme is subsequent to the binding of NADPH, and at the end of the reaction, the reduced product is released from the enzyme before the oxidized cofactor. Therefore, the motion from the “closed” to the “open” conformation of the safety-belt loop represents the rate-limiting step of the AR-catalyzed reduction of carbonyl substrates.(7)
    The AR active site is delimitated by prevalently hydrophobic amino acid residues, with the exception of few hydrophilic residues, consequently favoring the binding of lipophilic ligands over monosaccharides. In particular, in the active site cleft, certain polar amino acid residues, i.e., Asp43, Tyr48, Lys77, His110, Ser159, Asn160, Gln183, and Tyr209, form a rigid subsite in which a network of hydrogen bonds keeps the nicotinamide ring of the cofactor tightly bound and positioned for the transfer of the 4-pro-R hydride from NADPH to the carbon atom of the carbonyl group of the substrate during the catalytic reaction.(87) Among these residues, Tyr48 serves as proton donor to the carbonyl oxygen atom of the substrate during the second step of the reduction, whereas His110 maintains the proper orientation of the substrate in the active site. This subsite can serve as a polar recognition region able to anchor anionic and/or hydrogen bond acceptor groups of various substrates and inhibitors (Figure 5).
    In the AR active site, a second contiguous region is detectable, which is situated above the coenzyme and consists of a pocket lined with hydrophobic amino acid residues, such as Trp20, Trp79, Trp111 (this latter residue demarcates an edge between the two main regions of the AR active site), Phe122, Pro218, Trp219, Cys298, and Leu300. This hydrophobic zone includes a “specificity” pocket, also named “induced cavity region”, which is localized among Trp111, Thr113, Phe122, Ala299, Leu300, Ser302, and Cys303 (Figure 5)(87) and shows a high degree of flexibility in contrast with the rigid polar subsite around the cofactor. This pocket, in fact, can adopt different conformations depending on the size and nature of the ligand.(92) It was also proposed that the enzyme may exist in different conformational states and each ligand binds the most suitable conformation by stabilizing it and thus changing the conformational distribution of the protein.(92, 93)
    The binding of certain ARIs, such as tolrestat, zopolrestat, and minalrestat (Figure 1), to the enzyme induces a conformational change in two loops containing Phe122 and Leu300, respectively. As a consequence, the specificity pocket, which is closed in the apoenzyme crystal structure, becomes accessible to inhibitors, and thus, aromatic portions present in these ARIs, such as naphthalene, benzothiazole or 4-bromo-2-fluorophenyl moieties, can fit efficaciously this cavity (Figure 5).(87-89) Leu300 appears to act crucially as a gate-keeper which controls the access to the specificity pocket and can also affect the position of proximal residues, such as Phe122, Trp219, and Cys303.(92, 94)
    On the contrary, sorbinil (Figure 1), which possesses a compact structure lacking of a suitable hydrophobic portion, is not able to open the specificity pocket and, in fact, binds to an AR conformation with the specificity pocket in the closed state.(87)
    Therefore, induced-fit adaptation is not necessary for the binding to AR, but it can remarkably influence the effects of ligand-enzyme interaction. Indeed, among the members of the AKR superfamily, the amino acid residues present in the AR specificity pocket are less conserved than the hydrophilic residues of the active site, such as Tyr48 and His110, thus providing a structural basis for selective inhibition of AR. However, given the pronounced induced-fit adaptations and the number of possible binding-competent conformations that have been observed, even in AR crystals under varying cocrystallization conditions, AR remains a challenging target for structure-based drug design.(92, 95)
    The high flexibility of the binding site of AR may explain the wide variety of small molecule ligands (both substrates and inhibitors) that it can accommodate, though being able to discriminate among similar ligands.(87, 92) In fact, AR can recognize different substrates with either hydrophilic (such as glyceraldheyde and aldoses) or hydrophobic (such as HNE) structures, although it greatly prefers the latter, and it can accommodate inhibitors with different size and shape.
    In addition, AR reduces glutathione conjugates of aldehydes, such as GS-HNE, more efficiently than the corresponding free aldehydes. The enhanced catalytic efficiency of the enzyme toward glutathiolated substrates is mainly due to a selective recognition of the glutathione backbone within the AR binding site which shows a flexible glutathione-binding domain distinct from the aldehyde-binding region and largely coincident with the specificity pocket.(96, 97) In particular, the N-terminal glutamate and C-terminal glycine of glutathione may provide specific interactions particularly with Trp20, Leu301, and Ser302. Accordingly, substitutions at these positions in both glutathione-conjugated substrates and enzyme reduced the catalytic efficiency of AR.(96-98)
    A further feature that can influence AR activity is its high sensitivity to oxidants, which can inactivate the enzyme by modifying the reactive residue Cys298 present in the active site.(8, 99) In fact, in oxidative conditions, cellular glutathione is oxidized to glutathione disulfide, which may readily react with the thiol group of Cys298 to give a mixed disulfide that exhibits altered kinetic parameters with respect to the native enzyme, showing lower affinity toward substrates.(7, 100-102) It was proposed that the thiol/disulfide exchange may be a regulatory process that modulates AR activity providing a reversible modification capable of protecting the enzyme from irreversible damage caused by oxidative conditions.(100) It might also serve to prevent the consumption of the reducing cofactor NADPH in conditions of oxidative stress.(101)
    S-thiolated forms of the enzyme also show altered sensitivity to inhibitors. Modified forms of AR, which are less sensitive to ARIs, were found in patients with hyperglycemia, likely due to the oxidative stress condition associated with DM. This aspect appears to be particularly significant in view of the therapeutic use of ARIs, since it might explain, at least in part, the limited efficacy shown by certain inhibitors in long-term treatments of diabetic individuals,(7, 8) and it should be taken into account in developing ARIs as drugs.

    Challenges and Recent Advances in Developing Aldose Reductase Inhibitors as Drug Candidates

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The great number of ARIs discovered in the past 40 years show a wide variety of different chemical structures that, however, share certain molecular features. In fact, most ARIs bear an acidic group, which is capable of effectively anchoring the inhibitor to the polar positively charged recognition region of the AR catalytic site through ionic and/or hydrogen bonds. In addition, one or more aromatic moieties may contribute to ligand/enzyme binding by efficiently fitting the lipophilic region of the AR active site including the specificity pocket. These latter interactions may significantly affect the stability of inhibitor/enzyme complex as well as determine a proper orientation of the ligand into the cavity of the enzyme, which is prevalently lined by lipophilic amino acid residues. Moreover, hydrophobic moieties of ARIs involved in effective interactions with nonconserved amino acid residues in the specificity pocket can function as important selectivity determinants.
    Most known ARIs belong to the chemical classes of (i) cyclic imides, mostly spirohydantoins (such as sorbinil and fidarestat, Figure 1) or spirosuccinimides (such as minalrestat and ranirestat, Figure 1), and (ii) carboxylic acids (such as epalrestat, tolrestat, zopolrestat, ponalrestat, and zenarestat, Figure 1). Besides them, numerous structurally diverse ARIs were reported, including phenolic compounds (flavonoids, chalcones, curcumin, and other related natural and synthetic compounds), benfotiamine, sulfonylpyridazinone, and 4-thiazolidinone derivatives.(2, 4, 5, 19-22, 39, 103, 104)
    Cyclic imides were shown to be effective ARIs both in vitro and in vivo. In an attempt to avoid the phenytoin-like hypersensitivity reactions provoked by some of them, such as sorbinil, and attributed to the hydantoin moiety, safer bioisosters were designed and tested as ARIs, such as succinimides, 2,4-thiazolidinediones, and 2-thioxo-4-thiazolidinones, which include several efficacious ARIs with clinically suitable profiles.(4, 5, 19-22)
    Carboxylic acid derivatives emerged as potent ARIs, often remarkably more active than imides, because they are prevalently ionized at physiological pH values and therefore capable of establishing strong interactions with the positively charged recognition region of the AR active site. Although these features are favorable in order to enhance affinity for the target and inhibitory potency, in vivo they may determine a limited capability to cross biomembranes and consequently poor tissue penetration. However, certain carboxylic acid derivatives display favorable pharmacological properties, depending on the overall physicochemical features of molecules, and several of them, including epalrestat, proved to be effective in cell cultures or in vivo.(14, 22, 23, 27, 28)
    Capability of penetrating well into key target tissues, such as peripheral nerves, is a crucial property required for ARIs, and thus, although the reasons of the disappointing results of certain clinical trials are still debated, cellular permeability remains a major goal in the development of ARIs as drugs.
    Limiting unwanted effects is another unavoidable aim in the design of new ARIs and their optimization, especially considering that the prevention and management of diabetic complications require effective and safe drugs that have to be used in long-term therapies. In this view, the capability of discriminating between AR and other related AKRs is a desirable feature of ARIs as drug candidates.
    A novel approach in the search for ARIs is the design of molecules that are able to differentially block the activity of the enzyme toward glucose and glutathione-conjugated aldehydes without affecting the capability of AR to reduce free toxic aldehydes so that the cytotoxic role of AR in inflammatory signaling as well as in glucose metabolism can be prevented while its detoxifying function remains unaltered.

    (a) Design of Selective Aldose Reductase Inhibitors

    The scarcely selective inhibition of different AKRs related to AR, in particular aldehyde reductase (ALR1, AKR1A1), might be responsible for unwanted effects or inadequate therapeutic indexes observed during clinical investigation of several ARIs. ALR1 catalyzes the reduction of highly reactive toxic 2-oxoaldeydes, such as 3-deoxyglucosone and methylglyoxal, which participate in AGE formation and protein cross-linking. These aldehydes are formed in high amounts under hyperglycemic conditions and contribute to the tissue and vascular damage induced by prolonged exposure to high glucose concentrations.(105, 106) Therefore, the simultaneous inhibition of both AR and ALR1 may reduce the benefits provided by ARIs, by preventing the detoxifying function of ALR1.
    The significant similarity of sequence (more than 85% sequence homology) and overall architecture at the active sites of AR and ALR1 may be a challenge in identifying selective ARIs. However, the two enzymes show crucial differences in the substrate-binding site which can be exploited for designing selective inhibitors. In particular, Thr113, Ala299, and Leu300, which are present in the C-terminal loop flanking the AR specificity pocket, are replaced by Tyr116, Ile299, and Pro301, respectively, in ALR1, whereas Ser302 is replaced by an extra loop from Pro301 to Arg312. In addition, in the ALR1 active site, the nonconserved Arg312 and Asp313 appear to play critical roles in determining the binding to ligands.(94, 107, 108)
    Ligands able to open and occupy the specificity pocket of AR, such as tolrestat and zopolrestat, are generally unable to bind efficiently the corresponding amino acid residues of ALR1, thus inhibiting selectively AR. Accordingly, the absence of structural portions suitable to gain access to the specificity pocket can explain the nonselective action of some ARIs, such as sorbinil.(87) Diversely, the selective ARI fidarestat does not induce AR conformational changes but possesses an exocyclic amide group that can bind Leu300 and Trp219 of the target. In ALR1, Leu300 is replaced by a proline, which is unable to form H-bonds with the inhibitor. Thus, the amide chain of fidarestat appears to be the main feature of this compound which is responsible for the selective inhibition of AR over ALR1.(109-111)
    The high flexibility of the AR specificity pocket can be exploited in drug design to explore structural diversity, thus favoring the identification of novel chemotypes as potential selective ARIs, although the above-mentioned unpredictable conformational adaptation of AR induced by ligands may complicate the task of medicinal chemists.
    On this basis, in the past decade new potent and selective ARIs were identified by exploring molecules endowed with a hydrophobic moiety, generally a substituted heteroaromatic system, which is able to effectively interact with the AR specificity pocket by inducing a proper conformational adaptation of this region. In most cases, high affinity for the target was achieved by means of an acetic acid residue as hydrophilic head capable of anchoring the inhibitor to the polar recognition region of the AR active site.
    An interesting example of acetic acid based selective ARIs is a series of (2-arylcarbamoyl)phenoxyacetic acids and their carbamothioyl analogues which include the potent inhibitor (2-{[(4-bromo-2-fluorophenyl)methyl]carbamothioyl}-5-fluorophenoxy)acetic acid (5) (IDD594) (Figure 6).(112) X-ray crystallographic analysis highlighted that compound 5 is firmly bound within the AR active site through the carboxylate head which forms tight hydrogen bonds with Tyr48, His110, and Trp111 and a strong electrostatic interaction with NADP+. The binding of 5 to the enzyme induces a conformational change that opens the specificity pocket. This allows the 4-bromo-2-fluorobenzyl portion to fit this cavity and effectively interact with Ala299, Leu300, and Thr113, by assuming an orientation which can be superimposed to the same moiety of minalrestat.(113) The short contact between the bromine atom of 5 and the amino acid residue Thr113 of the enzyme appeared to be crucial in determining the high affinity of the inhibitor toward AR (more than 1000-fold higher than toward ALR1). In fact, Thr113 is replaced by a bulkier tyrosine in ALR1, thus causing steric hindrance and preventing interaction with the bromine atom.(114) Interestingly, compound 5 was shown to be active in vivo, determining reduced sorbitol accumulation in diabetic rat nerve.(112)
    Investigation of a different series of acetic acid derivatives led to the identification of a promising clinical candidate, 3-[(4,5,7-trifluorobenzothiazol-2-yl)methyl]indole-N-acetic acid (6) (lidorestat) (Figure 6), which was 5400-fold more active against AR than against ALR1.(115) The presence of fluorine substituents in positions 4, 5, and 7 of the benzothiazole system proved to be optimal for an effective binding to the target enzyme.(115) Furthermore, the replacement of the indole nucleus with the pyrrolo[2,3-b]pyridine isoster provided a significant gain in AR selectivity up to more than 14 000-fold over ALR1 (compound 7, Figure 6).(116) Once again, X-ray crystallography revealed that lidorestat and its pyrrolopyridine analogue 7 are strongly anchored within the AR active site by means of electrostatic interactions and hydrogen bonds of the carboxylate head with the polar recognition region of the target. The opened specificity pocket can accommodate the benzothiazole moiety which interacts with Trp111 and Leu300.(115, 116)
    Lidorestat exhibited a favorable pharmacokinetic profile, with good capability of penetrating tissues in which diabetic complications occur, such as nerve and lens. In fact, in diabetic rats, it was able to normalize sorbitol and fructose levels in nerve, to prevent cataracts and to reduce plasma triglyceride levels. In clinical trials, lidorestat administration also led to normalization of nerve sorbitol levels.(115)
    Acetic acid derivatives of 3,4-dihydro-2H-1,2,4-benzothiadiazine 1,1-dioxide (8, Figure 6) were also reported as potent ARIs endowed with in vivo activity.(117) Compound 8a was one of the most potent and selective in vitro inhibitors among these ARIs and showed appreciable ability to reduce sorbitol levels in diabetic rat nerve after oral administration.(117) SAR studies highlighted that the carboxylic group of the acetic chain is an important structural feature to determine AR inhibition. The substituted benzyl moiety played a central role in determining AR inhibitory effects, the 2,4,5-trifluorobenzyl ring being the most advantageous, while the insertion of a halogen in position 7 of the benzothiadiazine 1,1-dioxide scaffold was beneficial but not essential for activity. In a subsequent study, hydrophobic and bulky substituents (such as dialkylcarbamoyl moieties) in this position were found to be beneficial for both AR inhibitory activity and selectivity.(118) Similar SARs were observed in analogous (3,4-dihydro-2H-pyrido[2,3-e]-1,2,4-thiadiazine 1,1-dioxide)acetic acids (9, Figure 6).(119) Docking studies indicated that the benzothiadiazine moiety of compound 8a could fit the specificity pocket in the tolrestat-bound conformation of AR, positioning between Leu300 and Phe122, and it also appeared to control the orientation of the substituted benzyl ring in a near hydrophobic cavity delimited by Phe121, Phe122, Trp20, Val47, Tyr48.(117)
    In contrast, 3,3-dioxide-1,2-dihydronaphtho[1,2-d]-isothiazol-1-one acetic acid derivatives 10 and 11 (Figure 6),(120) initially designed as rigid analogues of tolrestat, were shown to bind an AR conformer with the specificity pocket in the closed state, similar to the sorbinil-bound conformation. However, compound 10, which acts as potent and selective ARI, was able to induce a displacement of Trp20 which determined the opening of a novel subpocket within the catalytic cavity of the enzyme. This subpocket can accommodate the naphthyl system, whereas the carboxylic group in position 4 of the scaffold points toward the polar region of the active site.(121, 122) Subsequent molecular simplification, by removing the central benzene ring from the naphto[1,2-d]isothiazole system, led to ARIs with a five-membered heterocyclic core, such as (1,2,4-oxadiazol-5-yl)acetic acid analogues 12 (Figure 6), most of which act as selective ARIs with IC50 values ranging from 0.27 to 28.4 μM toward AR and IC50 > 10 μM toward ALR1.(123) The most effective inhibitor of the series (compound 12a, Figure 6) possesses a 4-methoxyphenyl ring in position 3 of the oxadiazole core which can fit the AR specificity pocket in the 5-bound conformation, being trapped in the hydrophobic cavity formed by Trp79, Phe115, Phe122, and Leu300.(123)
    Recently, the selective AR inhibitory effects of certain (5-arylidene-2,4-dioxothiazolidin-3-yl)acetic acids were rationalized by means of X-ray crystallographic and computational studies.(124, 125) The carboxymethoxy group in position 3 of the benzylidene ring of compound 13 (Figure 6) can tightly bind the polar recognition region of both AR and ALR1, mainly by means of hydrogen bonds, whereas the (2,4-dioxothiazolidin-3-yl)acetic acid portion can reach the AR specificity pocket by interacting with Leu300 and Trp219. A more selective analogue (14, Figure 6) assumed a 180° flipped orientation, thus interacting with the backbone nitrogen atom of Leu300 through the 3-hydroxy group of the benzylidene portion, whereas the carboxylic group of the acetic chain on N-3 was bound to the polar recognition region. In ALR1 the amino acid residue Pro301 (Leu300 in AR) was incapable of producing efficacious interactions with the inhibitors; thus, the hydrogen bond contact with Leu300 appeared to be of particular importance for the selectivity of these ARIs. In addition, π-stacking interactions with Trp219 of AR contributed to affinity for the target, whereas the corresponding Trp220 of ALR1 adopted a different rotamer conformation which was less favorable for interaction with these inhibitors.(125)
    Compounds 3 (Figure 4) and 15–19 (Figure 6) are other examples of recently reported selective ARIs.(126-130) (1-Thioxo-1,2,3,4-tetrahydro-β-carbolin-9-yl)acetic acid 18(129) as well as β-glucogallin (3) and analogous amide 19(130) showed selectivity toward AR over both related ALR1 and AKR1B10. It was proposed that the benzyl group of 18 can fit the hydrophobic pocket of the AR active site by establishing effective interactions with Trp219, whereas the carboxylic group of the acetic chain in position 9 can bind Ser302. The benzyl moiety appeared to assume a different and less favorable orientation in AKR1B10.(129)
    Selectivity toward AR over AKR1B10 recently emerged as an additional aspect which could be evaluated in developing ARIs as potentially safe drugs, since simultaneous AKR1B10 inhibition might be related to the onset of unwanted effects. AKR1B10 is an AKR enzyme mainly expressed in human small intestine and adrenal gland. It shows 71% sequence identity and similar folding with human AR. AKR1B10 and AR also show almost overlapping substrate specificity, since AKR1B10 reduces a variety of substrates, such as HNE, glyceraldehyde, methylglyoxal, retinals, and aromatic aldehydes, which are also substrates for AR. Thus, this enzyme may contribute to the metabolization of toxic aldehydes by cooperating with AR.(131) In contrast, AKR1B10 is unable to reduce aldoses. The preference of AKR1B10 toward retinals, farnesal, geranylgeranial, and 20α-hydroxysteroids suggested that its main physiological role may be the metabolism of retinoids, isoprenoids, and steroids.(132, 133)
    On the other hand, AKR1B10 was found to be considerably overexpressed in liver, lung, and pancreatic tumors and adenocarcinomas, whereas AR overexpression is generally more marked in other human tumor types and leukemias.(77) In addition, analogous to AR, AKR1B10 was found to be linked to the development of drug resistance in cancer cells by catalyzing carbonyl reduction of certain anticancer drugs, such as anthracyclines,(134) and, thus, it is also considered as a potential novel target for antitumor chemotherapeutics. In this view, selectivity toward AR or AKR1B10 might be desirable in order to achieve specific management of tumor types which express different levels of these AKRs, whereas on the other hand, the nonselective inhibition of both enzymes might contribute to counteract drug resistance onset in cancer cells.
    Tolrestat and other known ARIs exhibited appreciable AKR1B10 inhibitory properties; however, they were found to be markedly more active against AR than against AKR1B10.(135)
    In contrast, certain nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs were shown to inhibit selectively AKR1B10 over AR, particularly N-phenylanthranilic acid derivatives (20, 21) and diclofenac (22) (Figure 7).(135) Other compounds (23–30) endowed with selective AKR1B10 inhibitory properties are depicted in Figure 7.(136-140) Among them, oleanolic acid (23)(139) and 3-(4-hydroxy-2-methoxyphenyl)acrylic acid 3-(3-hydroxyphenyl)propyl ester (24)(140) exhibited the highest selectivity levels toward AKR1B10 versus AR.
    Crystallographic analysis, molecular docking, and site-directed mutagenesis studies allowed the identification of selectivity determinants for AKR1B10. Amino acid residues in the active site of the enzyme, such as Lys125, Val301, Gln303, Gln114, Trp220, and Ser304, were shown to be critically involved in interactions with selective AKR1B10 inhibitors, by delimiting a cavity that, in analogy to AR, is named “specificity pocket”. In particular, a pivotal role of Val301 was recognized in determining inhibitor selectivity. This also provided an explanation of the high selectivity of fidarestat for AR versus AKR1B10. In fact, in AKR1B10 the interaction of the exocyclic amide group of fidarestat with Val301 (Leu300 in AR) is prevented by unfavorable steric contacts.(141)
    The orientation of the side chain of Trp112, a conserved residue (Trp111 in AR), was shown to be a further key feature for the binding of inhibitors to AKR1B10. In fact, this residue exists in a native “B10-position” in the holoenzyme, but it assumes a “AKR1B1-like” orientation in several complexes with ARIs. It is likely that ARIs, capable of inducing the opening of the AR specificity pocket, can produce a similar conformational change in AKR1B10, causing a flip of the Trp112 side chain to a position similar to that of Trp111 in AR. This could explain the limited selectivity of several ARIs, such as tolrestat and zopolrestat, relative to AKR1B10. In complexes of the enzyme with inhibitors unable to induce conformational changes in Trp112, this residue remains in the native AKR1B10 orientation which leaves a wide entrance to the anionic region, thus allowing the accommodation of inhibitors with wide structures, generally more bulky and rigid than those of ARIs.(142)

    (b) Design of Differential Aldose Reductase Inhibitors

    Compelling evidence indicates that unwanted or toxic effects of ARIs can be ascribed, at least in part, to the capability of inhibitors to block the detoxifying function of AR toward lipid-derived aldehydes.(7, 8)
    As described above, the reduction of highly reactive carbonyl metabolites derived from lipid peroxidation, such as HNE, is a prominent physiological function of AR. On the other hand, the AR-catalyzed conversion of the glutathione-conjugated aldehyde GS-HNE to GS-DHN is a crucial step in the propagation of oxidative stress, capable of sustaining oxidative and inflammatory signaling events and produce tissue injury.(7, 8, 39, 45)
    Therefore, it is desirable to design AR differential inhibitors (ARDIs), which could be developed as a novel generation of agents able to prevent the AR-catalyzed production of both GS-DHN and sorbitol and the consequent tissue injury, without affecting the detoxifying function of the enzyme.
    The antiprotozoal drug nitazoxanide (31, Figure 8), which proved to inhibit human AR with an IC50 value of 8.22 μM, was reported as a partial inhibitor of AR which might allow the enzyme to bind and reduce only certain substrates.(143) In fact, in the AR–NADP+–nitazoxanide ternary complex, the inhibitor was positioned into the hydrophobic pocket of the active site, whereas a cocrystallized molecule of dimethylformamide occupied the catalytic polar region in the same position that d-glyceraldehyde assumed in the active site of the enzyme. This suggested that nitazoxanide could leave an empty space, delimited by Trp219, Cys298, and Leu300, that might allow small molecule substrates, such as aldehydes, to enter the catalytic site, whereas the interaction with bulkier substrates, such as glucose or glutathione-conjugated aldehydes, might be prevented.(143)
    Indeed, the design of ARDIs can be mainly based on the possibility of occupying the hydrophobic region of the AR active site, which includes the specificity pocket, by means of small molecule inhibitors, in particular by establishing effective interactions with amino acid residues involved in the selective recognition of glutathione-conjugated aldehydes (such as Leu301 and Ser302). At the same time, the anion-binding site should be only partially occupied and, thus, accessible for the binding of free toxic aldehydes and their consequent reduction. This guideline could lead to the design of inhibitors which are unable to reach the anion-binding region at the bottom of the active site cavity but able to efficiently fit the upper hydrophobic pocket. Moreover, interactions with poorly conserved amino acid residues, such as Leu301 and Ser302, which line the specificity pocket, could simultaneously favor the selective inhibition of AR over other related enzymes.
    Starting from the crystal structures of AR cocrystallized with selective ARIs, such as zopolrestat and tolrestat, a recent computational study led to the rational design of potential ARDIs.(144) In these molecules (structures 32–36, Figure 8), two heteroaromatic moieties linked via a carbonyl group are present in order to maintain the capability of effectively fitting the specificity pocket and tightly interacting with amino acid residues, such as Trp111, Thr113, Leu300, and Cys303, through H-bonds and hydrophobic interactions, whereas acidic portions able to bind the anion-binding subsite were removed in order to leave this latter region partially unoccupied. When three substrates (glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, methylglyoxal, and glucose) were docked into the complex of AR–NADP+ with the potentially most active inhibitor (32, PI-1, Figure 8), glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate and methylglyoxal were shown to occupy the anion-binding region of the AR catalytic site, whereas glucose was unable to gain access to the active site and remained on the surface of the enzyme, thus suggesting that compound 32 might act as an ARDI.(144)
    More recently, a series of structurally different ARIs were tested by using l-glyceraldehyde (GAL) and HNE as substrates, and the differences in AR inhibition depending on the nature of the substrate were evaluated.(145) Out of the tested compounds, d-glyceramide (37) and d-gluconamide (38) (Figure 8) showed the highest differential inhibitory capability, by inhibiting the enzyme activity toward GAL more efficiently than toward HNE. d-Glyceramide also inhibited the AR-catalyzed conversion of GS-HNE to GS-DHN. However, the differential intrasite specificity was not associated with high inhibitory potency, since these compounds exerted AR inhibition at millimolar concentrations. Among ARIs with high affinity for the target, epalrestat and sorbinil were found to inhibit the reduction of both GAL and HNE almost to the same extent, whereas quercetin (Figure 1) exerted a moderate differential inhibition toward GAL reduction.(145) Instead, compounds 39 and 40 (Figure 8) were shown to inhibit the activity of AR at micromolar concentrations by blocking the AR-catalyzed reduction of both d-glucose and GS-HNE more efficiently than that of HNE. Therefore, they can be considerd lead compounds with a potential to be developed as effective ARDIs.(145)

    (c) Aldose Reductase Inhibitors Endowed with Antioxidant Properties

    The limited in vivo effectiveness observed with certain ARIs during clinical trials might be related, besides to poor capability of penetrating target tissues, to the post-translational modifications of AR that occur under oxidative conditions. In fact, in both DM and different inflammatory pathologies, increased cellular oxidative stress induces oxidation of the critical amino acid residue Cys298 in the active site of AR as well as promotes the generation of S-thiolated forms of the enzyme with reduced sensitivity to inhibitors.(7, 8, 100-102)
    On this basis, therapeutic treatments with ARIs combined with antioxidants could be a useful strategy in order to prevent the oxidative modifications of the enzyme that may be responsible for drug resistance, thus keeping the target in its ARI-sensitive reduced form. In addition, antioxidants could act synergistically with ARIs by contributing to counteract oxidative stress derived from hyperglycemia and/or inflammation.(8)
    In view of this, compounds endowed with dual activity as ARIs and antioxidants were identified in the past decade. Previously, flavonoids (such as quercetin, Figure 1) were described in the literature as compounds endowed with both AR inhibitory and antioxidant effects, but none of them showed clinically suitable profiles, especially because of their high hydrophilicity and low oral bioavailability.(20) However, both flavones and isoflavones remain attractive molecules, since they possess structural features corresponding to certain pharmacophoric requirements for AR inhibition, such as acidic phenol groups, which could effectively interact with the anion-binding region of the AR active site, and the benzopyranone nucleus, which is potentially able to bind the enzyme through both hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions.
    Among these natural compounds, genistein (41, Figure 9), which is an isoflavinoid found in soy beans, appears to be a promising agent, showing both AR inhibitory activity and remarkable antioxidant effectiveness. It was able to increase the cellular levels of glutathione in high glucose-treated lens epithelial cells and to prevent xylose-induced cataractogenesis in an ex vivo assay.(146)
    Recently, the pyrido[1,2-a]pyrimidin-4-one scaffold was reported as a bioisoster of the flavone system.(147) The presence of a hydroxy substituent in position 6 of this scaffold was beneficial for AR inhibitory activity and, along with the insertion of a 3,4-dihydroxyphenyl moiety in position 2, led to the most potent and selective ARI of this series endowed with significant antioxidant activity (compound 42, Figure 9).(147) Docking and molecular dynamics simulations into the AR active site suggested that, as expected, the dissociated hydroxy groups present on the phenyl ring in position 2 could simulate the interactions between a carboxylic group and the anion-binding region of the enzyme, whereas the pyridopyrimidine nucleus could fit the specificity pocket, thus accounting for the observed AR selectivity over ALR1.(147)
    Another example of compounds with dual activity was given by structural analogues of the potent antioxidant stobadine (43, Figure 9). Tetrahydropyridoindoles (44, Figure 9) were found to be more effective and selective ARIs than their hexahydropyridoindole congeners 45, whereas these latter showed better radical scavenging and antioxidant properties.(148)
    Novel benzofuroxane derivatives, based on a parent compound previously identified by means of a virtual screening (compound 63, Figure 10), showed AR inhibitory and antioxidant properties, besides an additional NO donor activity. Among them, compounds 46a,b (Figure 9) displayed promising profiles as both ARI and radical scavenger agents, being significantly more effective than α-tocopherol in reducing hydroxyl radical-dependent lipoperoxidation induced in rat brain homogenate.(149) 5-Arylidene-4-thiazolidinone-based ARIs 47, 48 (Figure 9) were also shown to act as excellent antioxidant agents which were more effective than the reference α-tocopherol in the same assay.(150)

    (d) Improving Bioavailability of Aldose Reductase Inhibitors

    Different approaches may be applied in order to improve cell permeability and bioavailability of ARIs.
    The presence of large hydrophobic moieties in the structure of numerous compounds, described above as selective ARIs, is beneficial for their AR affinity and selectivity, by means of effective interactions with the specificity pocket of the enzyme, and at the same time can influence activity by enhancing hydrophobicity of molecules and consequently improving their capability to cross biomembranes. This gain in lipophilicity can account for the bioavailability of many carboxylic acid containing ARIs (e.g., epalrestat, zopolrestat, ponalrestat, 5, and lidorestat, Figures 1 and 6) that, although highly ionized at physiological pH values, exhibit excellent in vivo activity. The insertion of small lipophilic substituents, such as fluorine or bromine atoms, on the aromatic systems of these ARIs was also shown to improve both their affinity for the target and cell permeability.(112, 114, 115)
    It was also proposed that zwitterionic forms of amphoteric agents might be interesting in order to achieve acceptable in vivo distribution, due to their lipophilicity profile. In certain ampholytes, lipophilicity reaches a maximum value at the isoelectric point, thus giving potentially enhanced partitioning for the doubly charged zwitterionic species compared to the single charged ions. Therefore, it was suggested that the design of amphoteric agents with isoelectric point at physiological pH values might be exploited to obtain ARIs with improved pharmacokinetics.(148) However, the poor water solubility of amphoteric compounds at their isoelectric point should be taken into consideration as a possible drawback.
    Non-carboxylic acid containing molecules with low ionization potential at physiological pH values may be designed and explored as ARIs potentially endowed with good cellular permeability.
    An excellent example of low molecular weight, selective, and potent non-carboxylic acid, non-hydantoin ARIs reported in the past decade was provided by a class of arylsulfonylpyridazinone derivatives, out of which 6-(5-chloro-3-methylbenzofuran-2-sulfonyl)-2H-pyridazin-3-one (49, Figure 10) was shown to be the best inhibitor exhibiting significant in vitro effectiveness (IC50 = 1 nM) and remarkable selectivity (930-fold) toward human AR over ALR1.(151, 152) It also displayed favorable pharmacokinetic properties, with high oral bioavailability, and was able to block the flux of glucose through the polyol pathway in nerve, retina, and lens of diabetic rats, with greater efficacy than both zopolrestat and sorbinil.(152, 153) X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that the pyridazinone headgroup of compound 49 binds the polar anion-binding region of the AR active site by establishing an H bond with Trp111 and a charge-assisted interaction with the positively charged nicotinamide moiety of NADP+ through the deprotonated and negatively charged N-2 atom of the pyridazinone ring as well as H-bonds with His110 and Tyr48 through the carbonyl oxygen in position 3. The chloro-substituted benzofuran system can occupy the specificity pocket of the enzyme, thus allowing a rationalization of the marked selectivity of this ARI.(154)
    2,4-Thiazolidinedione and 2-thioxo-4-thiazolidinone rings were also exploited as scaffolds for the design of non-carboxylic acid containing ARIs, being considered as safer bioisosters of the hydantoin ring. 2-Thioxo-4-thiazolidinone derivatives generally exhibited greater AR inhibitory potency than their 2,4-thiazolidinedione analogues.(22, 155) These findings could be ascribed to additional favorable interactions of the ligands within the AR active site, as recently reported for compounds 50, 51 (Figure 10).(72) In fact, N-unsubstituted 2-thioxo-4-thiazolidinones 51 were shown to be from twice to more than 30-fold more effective inhibitors than their 2,4-thiazolidinedione counterparts 50, by exhibiting IC50 values in the range from 1.08 to 11.6 μM.(72, 156)
    Non-carboxylic acid containing 4-thiazolidinone-based ARIs with a different substitution pattern on the heterocyclic scaffold (compounds 52, Figure 10) also displayed AR inhibitory activity at micromolar concentrations (IC50 = 2.54–36.1 μM), with selectivity over ALR1 likely related to interactions of the aromatic ring in position 3 of the thiazolidinone ring with amino acid residues lining the specificity pocket of AR.(157)
    Starting from carboxylic acid containing lead compounds that exhibit molecular features appropriate for binding AR, the replacement of the highly ionized carboxylic heads with less ionized bioisosters is a straightforward strategy often used to achieve inhibitors with potentially improved capability to cross cell membrane. Recently, this approach led to the discovery of effective ARIs, although in some cases they displayed lower affinity for the target enzyme than the carboxylic acid containing parents.
    A prominent example of lipophilic bioisoster of carboxylic acid containing portions is the 2,6-difluorophenol moiety, which was inserted in N-(3,5-difluoro-4-hydroxyphenyl)benzenesulfonamides (compounds 53, Figure 10) recently investigated as non carboxylic acid-containing ARIs.(158) Although their activity levels were in a wide micromolar range, they showed improved potency in comparison to the corresponding N-benzenesulfonylglycine analogues. Both the presence of an electron-releasing group in the para position of the benzene ring and the insertion of a 4-bromo-2-fluoromethylbenzyl moiety on the sulfonamide nitrogen atom were found to be favorable for the activity (e.g., compound 53a, IC50 = 0.397 μM, Figure 10).(159) In addition, some of these 2,6-difluorophenol substituted ARIs exhibited significant antioxidant potential.(158, 159) When the 2,6-difluorophenol portion was replaced by other possible biososters of the carboxylic group, such as a sulfonamide functionality, a tetrazole, or a isoxazolidin-3-one ring, a reduction of the inhibitory potency was observed versus an increase in selectivity toward AR over ALR1.(159)
    The 2,6-difluorophenol moiety was also used for bioisosteric replacement of the acetic acid chain of benzoylpyrrol-1-ylacetic acids to give compounds 54, 55 (Figure 10), most of which were endowed with AR inhibitory activity in the low micromolar/submicromolar range (IC50 = 0.19–9.93 μM) and generally appreciable selectivity over ALR1.(160, 161) Compound 55a also exhibited antioxidant properties and was able to reduce sorbitol accumulation in isolated rat lenses incubated in the presence of high glucose concentrations.(160) The carboxylic acid head of benzoylpyrrol-1-ylacetic acid derivatives was also replaced by a tetrazole ring, a commonly used bioisoster of carboxylic acids which is more lipophilic than the carboxylic group, despite that it is also ionized at physiological pH values. However, although the tetrazole ring appeared to mimic the carboxylate in anchoring the molecules to the anion-binding region of the AR active site, these bioisosters displayed reduced AR inhibitory activity compared to the carboxylic acid-containing analogues.(162) Subsequently, the 1-hydroxypyrazole ring was introduced on the same scaffold as a new acetic acid bioisoster endowed with a higher pKa value than both carboxylic acid and tetrazole. Among the synthesized compounds, biphenyl substituted derivative 56 (Figure 10) was proposed as a lead compound, being endowed with an IC50 value of 0.698 μM and appreciable selectivity related to ALR1.(163)
    More recently, benzoylpyrrole analogues were obtained by inserting a 2-fluorophenol moiety on the pyrrole nitrogen atom, out of which compounds 57a,b (Figure 10) emerged as promising ARIs, with IC50 values of 1.04 and 0.443 μM, respectively. Compounds 57a,b were also able to reduce sorbitol accumulation in isolated rat lenses incubated with glucose, and 57b displayed an appreciable ability to permeate rat jejunum.(164)
    Other bioisosters of carboxylic acid containing ARIs were obtained by replacing the acetic chain of (5-arylidene-2,4-dioxothiazolidin-3-yl)acetic acids (58, Figure 10) with different isosteric groups. The insertion of an acetamide, N-hydroxyacetamide, or 3,3,3-trifluoro-2-oxopropyl chain on N-3 of the thiazolidinedione ring (compounds 59–61, Figure 10) produced a general decrease in the AR inhibitory effect compared to the parent carboxylic acids, particularly for amide derivatives 59. However, among compounds 59–61, which are mainly nonionized at physiological pH values, inhibitors active at low micromolar concentrations (IC50 = 1.79–8.3 μM) were identified.(165, 166) These inhibition data prompt further evaluation of selected compounds on cell cultures and/or in vivo.
    Structurally diverse non-carboxylic acid containing ARIs were identified by means of a virtual screening.(167) Out of them, compounds 62, 63 (Figure 10) were shown to be active in vitro with IC50 values of 31.08 and 35.61 μM, respectively. The sulfonate group present in both of them might interact differently with the AR active site, as suggested by docking simulations, since the SO2 group of compound 62 was positioned in the anion-binding pocket, whereas compound 63 inserted its benzoxadiazole ring in the same subsite.(167)
    Finally, the common presence of a carboxylic group in the structure of many potent ARIs offers the opportunity to synthesize esters as prodrugs more lipophilic than parent acids. An example was provided by compound 10 (Figure 6)(120) that was converted to the corresponding isopropyl diester. This latter provided appreciable reduction of cataract incidence when topically administered as ophthalmic solution in galactosemic rats, contrary to the parent compound.(120)

    Concluding Remarks and Future Prospectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    It is definitely established that AR plays pivotal roles in mediating oxidative and inflammatory signaling events which are crucially involved in the pathogenic course of DM and its chronic complications as well as in the development of different pathologies not associated with DM.
    The recent findings regarding the pathophysiological functions of AR have encouraged the search for new effective and safe ARIs, thus prompting medicinal chemists to find new strategies to tackle old challenges in targeting this apparently evasive enzyme. Despite the difficulties encountered during investigation of ARIs as potential therapeutic agents, it can be expected that the current enhanced knowledge of structural and functional features of AR will allow the identification of new inhibitors with improved properties for drug development in the near future.
    In the search for new ARIs as potential drug candidates, identifying inhibitors endowed with good capability to cross biomembranes as well as devoid of serious unwanted effects is the main challenge for medicinal chemists. Modulating the capability of molecules to act as selective and/or differential inhibitors appears to be a pivotal approach to obtain ARIs with improved safety profiles.
    Certain structural features introduced in a template of potential ARIs could be useful to optimize more than one property of the molecule. For example, the presence of appropriate hydrophobic moieties able to open and fit the specificity pocket can achieve the goal of a selective interaction with AR over related enzymes and at the same time it can favor the differential inhibition of AR, in order to retain its detoxifying function and block the AR-catalyzed production of cytotoxic metabolites. Moreover, it can facilitate the partitioning of compounds to target tissues.
    In this context, we believe that the search for ARDIs is a challenging future direction that could be considered as a priority goal. In our opinion, the discovery of ARDIs with proper druglike features could represent a crucial turning point in the difficult route to develop inhibitors of AR useful as therapeutic agents, likely leading to a new generation of safer ARIs. This might facilitate the selection of new candidates with suitable safety profiles to be submitted to clinical trials. However, this is a recent approach that, up to now, has been reported in very few investigations and needs to be further developed.
    In addition, considering that the increased oxidative stress associated with DM and inflammation could interfere with the effectiveness of ARIs in vivo, the search for dual agents endowed with both AR inhibitory and antioxidant properties is considered as another promising strategy.
    At the same time, as suggested by several authors, a desirable advance in the development of ARIs could be to perform further biological screenings and clinical trials aimed at the treatment of inflammation and cancer, possibly starting from known ARIs with good pharmacokinetic and safety profiles, such as epalrestat, fidarestat, and ranirestat. This would allow the assessment of the efficacy of these agents in preventing or suppressing oxidative stress and chronic inflammation, which are closely related critical events in the onset and progression of different pathologies associated or not with DM, thus providing findings useful for developing novel agents targeted to the treatment of inflammation-based diseases.

    1. 1
      Brownlee, M. Biochemistry and Molecular Cell Biology of Diabetic Complications Nature 2001, 414, 813– 820
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Biochemistry and molecular cell biology of diabetic complications
      Brownlee, Michael
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2001), 414 (6865), 813-820CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Diabetes-specific microvascular disease is a leading cause of blindness, renal failure and nerve damage, and diabetes-accelerated atherosclerosis leads to increased risk of myocardial infarction, stroke and limb amputation. Four main mol. mechanisms have been implicated in glucose-mediated vascular damage. All seem to reflect a single hyperglycemia-induced process of overprodn. of superoxide by the mitochondrial electron-transport chain. This integrating paradigm provides a new conceptual framework for future research and drug discovery.
